prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Science Goal (B3 CO 92GHz, targets 1-3 within 10deg of each other)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: In this Science Goal, we perform single continuum observations at sky frequency 92 HGz. We observe 3 targets within 10 degrees of each other on the sky, in the frequency range of the CO(6-5) line redshifted at 6.5<z<7.2. All targets share the same correlator setup and calibration strategy that optimizes observing efficiency of ALMA.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
To detect CO(6-5) line at redshift range 6.5<z<7.2 we need to cover the frequency range between 84 and 92 GHz. However, spectral scan is not allowed for multiple pointings. Therefore, we set up two continuum observations at low (92GHz) and high (96GHz) sky frequencies and separate them into two Science Goals: Science Goal (B3 CO 92GHz, targets 1-3 within 10deg of each other) and Science Goal (B3 CO 96GHz, targets 1-3 within 10deg of each other).
We expect that our galaxies have a broad linewidth of 500km/s as was seen in the previous observations by Wang et al. (2010). Therefore, we select spectral resolution of 105km/s with averaging set to 1.

In ALMA Cycle 0 observation, the typical source sizes of our targets in dust continuum are 0.2-0.5", which corresponds to a few kpc at z~6 (Wang et al. 2013). Therefore, to efficiently observe them, it is important to use a comparable beam size. For bright objects we also have good chances to resolve the velocity field as was done in Wang et al. (2013) with 0.7" resolution in Cycle 0.

Our sensitivity calculation is based on the observations of known z~6 QSOs with CO detection. Wang et al. (2010) detected the CO(6-5) line in six z~6 QSOs. The line peak flux density is typically 1.5 mJy per beam (FWHM~5", PdBI), and the median line width is about 500km/s.
Optical brightness of our targets is similar to Wang et al. sample. Assuming a similar SED shape, we expect that the CO line flux is also similar.
Therefore, we aim to reach similar RMS with ALMA. In ALMA Cycle 0 observation, the typical source sizes of z~6 QSO host galaxies in dust continuum are 0.2-0.5" (Wang et al. 2013). In the requested spatial resolution (0.5"), we will detect them as a point source. Also our spectral resolution is 105km/s. We want to detect peak line flux at more than 3 sigma. Therefore, the requested sensitivity is 40 microJy. Brighter sources will be detected at a higher S/N ratio.
Our bandwidth is large because we perform a spectral scan. Our main focus is detection of the emission line. Therefore, S/N less than 3 for continuum of ~ 0.1 mJy is fine with us.

To detect CO(6-5) line at redshift range 6.5<z<7.2 we need to cover the frequency range between 84 and 92 GHz. However, spectral scan is not allowed for multiple pointings. Therefore, we set up two continuum observations at low and high sky frequencies and separate them into two Science Goals. To maximize frequency coverage from 84 to 92 GHz we set up a non standard sky frequncy of 92 GHz.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA spectroscopy of 23 QSO candidates at z>6.5 selected from the new PanSTARRS1 3pi survey. Our goal is to build a statistical sample of z> 6.5 QSOs, which is crucial for understanding of the reionization epoch and growth of the supermassive black holes in the early Universe. All targets are clear z-band dropouts (detectable only in the y band) with faint/no detection in WISE. This makes them very promising high-redshift QSO candidates. We propose a new and more efficient spectroscopic survey, by spectral scanning CO(6-5) emission in ALMA Band 3. The redshifted CO(6-5) line is between 84 and 92 GHz. Therefore, we only need two tunings to scan the CO line at 6.5<z<7.2. Photo-z uncertainty in this case does not cost extra-time because two tunings are still needed for continuum observation. In contrast, the spectral scan using the [CII] line is impractical because at the higher frequency range it requires at least 5 tunings. The CO observation takes only several mins per source, and thus is even more efficient than optical spectroscopy (~2 h per source). By using the CO spectral scanning for the first time with QSOs, we aim to increase the sample of known z~6.5 QSOs.
